title: Fatigue, Sleep Disorders, and Myasthenia Gravis

content: Living with myasthenia gravis (MG) is like playing an endless game of energy roulette. You never know when your body is going to tap out.

Fatigue is one of the most frustrating symptoms, but it’s not just the usual “I need a coffee” kind of tiredness. It’s an all-consuming, muscle-draining exhaustion that no amount of power naps can fix.

At my worst, my sleep was a disaster. I was going to bed at 3 a.m., waking up late, and then needing naps just to function. But these weren’t refreshing little catnaps; they were the “I still feel like I’ve been hit by a bus” variety.
No matter how much I rested, I never truly felt restored.

For a long time, I couldn’t figure out why my sleep was so out of sync. Then I came across something interesting: Women’s circadian rhythms are different from men’s, and hormonal changes throughout the month can affect sleep patterns. It turns out many women actually need more rest at certain times in their cycle.

content: That explained part of the issue, but it didn’t explain why my fatigue was so unrelenting. MG was, of course, the biggest culprit. But another sneaky villain was low iron.

Iron deficiency is common in people with MG, though not directly caused by the condition. It’s often a side effect of chronic inflammation, reduced appetite, or even steroid use, which can mess with absorption. The problem is, low iron can make fatigue exponentially worse, adding another layer of exhaustion to an already energy-draining condition.

Once I learned this, I started taking iron supplements. While it didn’t instantly transform me into a boundless ball of energy, it certainly helped. Slowly but surely, I began piecing together ways to fix my sleep and lessen my fatigue.

One of the best decisions I made was getting the Philips SmartSleep Wake-up Light. Instead of being jolted awake by an alarm that felt like a personal attack, I started waking up gradually to a soft, simulated sunrise.

content: The science behind it is simple. Our bodies are naturally programmed to wake up with the rising sun, thanks to our circadian rhythm, which regulates sleep and wakefulness based on light exposure. By gradually increasing light before waking, the lamp mimics a natural sunrise, triggering your body to reduce melatonin (the sleep hormone) and increase cortisol levels, helping you wake more gently and feel more alert in the morning. Over time, this helped stabilize my sleep cycle and made falling asleep at night much easier.

I also looked into magnesium, which is known to help with sleep. But here’s where things got tricky. Magnesium supplements can be dangerous for people with MG. In some cases, they can trigger a myasthenic crisis, which isn’t exactly the kind of risk you want to take for the sake of a slightly better night’s sleep.

I did hear that low-dose magnesium bisglycinate might be better tolerated. But rather than gambling with my health, I opted for the safer route – magnesium-rich foods. Every night before bed, I started eating a handful of nuts, seeds, or dark chocolate (because let’s be real, if I have to eat something for my health, I’d rather it be chocolate).

content: Little by little, my sleep began to improve. I finally had a consistent sleep schedule, and while I wouldn’t say I wake up bouncing with energy, I’m no longer stuck in the endless cycle of exhaustion that once controlled my life.

That being said, MG fatigue is still a beast. No matter how well I sleep, I don’t always feel fully rested, and I still need more downtime than most people. It’s something I’ve had to come to terms with. Pushing through exhaustion only makes things worse, so I’ve learned to give myself permission to rest when I need it.
If there’s one thing MG has taught me, it’s that you have to work with your body, not against it.

Regulating my sleep, improving my iron levels, and being mindful of what I put into my body have all made a difference. And while I may never be someone who wakes up feeling 100% refreshed, I’m at least in a place where I’m no longer completely at the mercy of my fatigue.

content: For anyone else struggling with sleep and MG, my advice is simple. Get your iron checked, create a bedtime routine that actually works for you, and be cautious with supplements. Most importantly, listen to your body. If it needs rest, give it rest. And if it needs a bit of dark chocolate before bed. … Well, who am I to argue with science?
